entry.def: The only word that corresponds to a notion of an event occurring is yǒu 有.

sense.def: have happened 有諸 "has this happened"
it happens, that S
未嘗有 “this has never happened" the event described in S has never happened.

= you4 又 'again'

entry.def: Yǒu 有 can come to refer to the more or less lasting result of the process of annexation. See GOVERN. [COMMENDATORY], [FORMAL], [INCHOATIVE], [LASTING], [STATE] >>INCHOATIVE, STATE, LASTING, COMMENDATORY, FORMAL

entry.def: Wéi 為, yǒu 有, yòng 用, lín 臨, lì 蒞, lǐ 理 are polite ways of referring to the government by a legitimate ruler.

sense.def: be formally or effectively in political control of (a state); control 有國
come to control, come to ruler over, come to be in charge of 有國"take over govt"

entry.def: Yǒu 有 (ant. wú 無 "there is no such fact")refers abstractly to the occurrence of an event or the truth of an abstract proposition.

sense.def: there is such a (state of affairs) 有之，有諸？"is that so?

entry.def: The most general word for all manner of property is yǒu 有, which refers to anything one has, but this usage is rare.

entry.def: The standard word for existence is yǒu 有.

entry.def: The standard current word for having in general is yǒu 有.
